abstract.text: An interface that allows a player to invite other players to a real-time game and automatch to fill any empty slots.

inlineContent.text: object and configure it according to the parameters of your game. Then pass the match request to the
initializer to create the view controller.

Configure the view controller and set its delegate before you present it to the local player. The view controller allows the local player to choose other players and, optionally, fill empty slots using automatch. If you add the Group Activities capability to your Xcode project, the player can invite others using SharePlay. See
protocols to handle when players send and accept invitations. Implement the
object, which you create using the
initializer, to the player who accepts an invitation. Then, implement the
delegate method to dismiss the view controller and start the game when all players accept their invitations.
In iOS, you present and dismiss the view controller from another view controller in your game, using the methods from the
class. If you use SwiftUI, you can get the root view controller from the

For visionOS games, the view controller appears anchored to the window, scene, or view relative to where you present the view controller. For immersive games, set the parent window to a separate window group than the immersive space window group.
class to present and dismiss the view controller.

abstract.text: The centralized point of control and coordination for apps running in iOS.
An object that manages a view hierarchy for your UIKit app.
Leverage FaceTime infrastructure to create coordinated experiences users can share.
Enable players to interact with friends, compare leaderboard ranks, earn achievements, and participate in multiplayer games.
An object that provides the ability to present the dashboard in macOS games.
An invitation to join a match sent to the local player from another player.
A protocol that handles invite events from Game Center.
Handles the event when the local player accepts an invitation from another player.
A protocol that handles events for Game Center players.
A peer-to-peer network between a group of players that sign into Game Center.
An object that encapsulates the parameters to create a real-time or turn-based match.
An object that creates matches with other players without presenting an interface to the players.
An interface that allows a player to invite other players to a real-time game and automatch to fill any empty slots.
Invites additional players to join an existing match.
A Boolean value that indicates whether your game can start after a minimum number of players join a match.
The default invitation message sent to a player.
Creates a matchmaker view controller to present to a player who accepts an invitation.
Creates a matchmaker view controller for the local player to start inviting other players.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the match is hosted or peer-to-peer.
The configuration for the desired match.
The object that handles matchmaker view controller changes.
The mode that a multiplayer game uses to find players.
Updates a playerâ€™s status on the view to show that the player has connected or disconnected from your server.
Updates the connection status of a player in a hosted game.
Informs the controller that a player has joined a hosted match.
An object that handles when the status of matchmaking changes.
Handles when the view controller finds players for a peer-to-peer match.
Possible modes that a multiplayer game uses to find matches.
The abstract base protocol adopted by GameKit view controller classes.
Enable players to voice chat with all, or groups of, players in a multiplayer game.

abstract.text: Create a more customized and optimized gaming experience by using matchmaking rules to find players in a real-time game.

abstract.text: Game Center applies different type of rules you create in a particular order to find the best matches.
A controller that manages a view, typically loaded from a nib file.
A container view controller that defines a stack-based scheme for navigating hierarchical content.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The interface an app extension uses to respond to a request from a host app.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A set of methods that support the mediation of a custom segue.
Methods that responder subclasses implement to support key binding commands, such as inserting tabs and newlines, or moving the insertion point.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
A protocol that marks classes to restore the state of your app to continue a user activity.
A set of methods used to associate a unique identifier with objects in your user interface.
An interface that provides a source for shareable content to fulfill user requests to share current content.
A protocol that a class must adopt to allow appearance customization using the [`UIAppearance`](doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIAppearance) API.
A set of methods for adapting the contents of your view controllers to size and trait changes.
A set of methods that define the focus behavior for a branch of the view hierarchy.
The interface that determines whether a responder object supports paste configuration.
A set of standard methods that apps can adopt to support editing.
Methods for adding objects to your state restoration archives.
A set of methods that makes the iOS interface environment available to your app.
The protocol you adopt to restore an objectâ€™s state from a user activity.
A type that calls your code in reaction to changes in the trait environment.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
